content.raw: There are helper functions for converting to Celsius and Fahrenheit, but I believe this code is using Kelvin as the internal unit and the default display value with the stream `<<` operator, so I think we agree.
content.html: There are helper functions for converting to Celsius and Fahrenheit, but I believe this code is using Kelvin as the internal unit and the default display value with the stream << operator, so I think we agree.

content.raw:
This is very interesting, I'm not sure how you feel about unit system in gazebo, but for example SDF (*) uses -9.8 for gravity, which is very natural for me like people who lives in meter unit system.
But I suppose since people in US use inch/pound in their daily life, so it is not easy for them to use meter/kg. I imagine that they talk like "Let's make 5 pound - 10 inch squire block in empty world", and internally convert to meter/kg and create sdf world model for gazebo.
And I think they always want to use inch/pound, but obey to use meter/kg with patient, in order to avoid confusion between meter and inch.
If this is the case, I think we have same situation between C/F, F is only used in US(**) and keep using C as default value in gazebo, and try not to use F as much as possible to avoid confusion.
Of course, good question may be why not use K for default unit for temperature since that is a part of SI unit system, and my answer is I usually uses C in may daily life and also scientific discussion, so I understand why you want to show the result in F ;-)

* http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=physics, 
** https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fahrenheit#Usage

![Countries_that_use_Fahrenheit.svg.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/dg5enz/images/155433650-Countries_that_use_Fahrenheit.svg.png)
content.html:
This is very interesting, I'm not sure how you feel about unit system in gazebo, but for example SDF () uses -9.8 for gravity, which is very natural for me like people who lives in meter unit system. But I suppose since people in US use inch/pound in their daily life, so it is not easy for them to use meter/kg. I imagine that they talk like "Let's make 5 pound - 10 inch squire block in empty world", and internally convert to meter/kg and create sdf world model for gazebo. And I think they always want to use inch/pound, but obey to use meter/kg with patient, in order to avoid confusion between meter and inch. If this is the case, I think we have same situation between C/F, F is only used in US(*) and keep using C as default value in gazebo, and try not to use F as much as possible to avoid confusion. Of course, good question may be why not use K for default unit for temperature since that is a part of SI unit system, and my answer is I usually uses C in may daily life and also scientific discussion, so I understand why you want to show the result in F ;-)

  • http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=physics, ** https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fahrenheit#Usage

the following test case fails:

diff -r 6e5083471021 src/Temperature_TEST.cc
--- a/src/Temperature_TEST.cc   Mon May 09 14:17:20 2016 -0700
+++ b/src/Temperature_TEST.cc   Fri May 20 14:22:04 2016 -0700
@@ -134,6 +134,16 @@
 }

 /////////////////////////////////////////////////
+TEST(TemperatureTest, Diff)
+{
+  Temperature inside, outside, diff;
+  inside.SetCelsius(25);
+  outside.SetCelsius(5);
+  diff = outside - inside;  // should be -20 C
+  EXPECT_EQ(diff, -20);
+}
+
+/////////////////////////////////////////////////
 TEST(TemperatureTest, OperatorStreamOut)
 {
   Temperature temp(55.45);

for example:

Temperature inside, outside, diff;
inside.SetCelsius(25);
outside.SetCelsius(5);
diff = outside - inside;  // should be -20 C

content.raw: This makes sense for absolute temperature, but it makes it difficult to use for temperature differences, which can be negative.
content.html: This makes sense for absolute temperature, but it makes it difficult to use for temperature differences, which can be negative.

content.raw: makes sense
content.html: makes sense

content.raw:
Maybe in the future. The `>>` operator needs to read what this operator generates. It will be somewhat difficult to start handling text strings which could be of many different forms: 

`1.0C, 1.0 C, 1.2Celsius, 1.2 K, etc.`

We have stated in the doxygen that the default unit is kelvin, so there shouldn't be any confusion.
content.html:
Maybe in the future. The >> operator needs to read what this operator generates. It will be somewhat difficult to start handling text strings which could be of many different forms:

1.0C, 1.0 C, 1.2Celsius, 1.2 K, etc.

We have stated in the doxygen that the default unit is kelvin, so there shouldn't be any confusion.
